abstract.p: George Jochnowitz letter says darkness in restaurants has taken away half the pleasure of eating out in New York (S)

block.p: Darkness in restaurants is a misfortune -- a curse -- that has taken away half the pleasure of eating out in this city of great food. In ''Dining by Flashlight: Restaurants Fade to Black'' (June 7), Amanda Hesser tells us about waiters who carry little flashlights and diners who can't recognize the food on their plates. Yet somehow, she approves. ''It was sexy,'' she writes.
Nonsense. People are beautiful and beauty is sexy -- if it is visible.

Darkness in restaurants is a misfortune -- a curse -- that has taken away half the pleasure of eating out in this city of great food. In ''Dining by Flashlight: Restaurants Fade to Black'' (June 7), Amanda Hesser tells us about waiters who carry little flashlights and diners who can't recognize the food on their plates. Yet somehow, she approves. ''It was sexy,'' she writes.
Nonsense. People are beautiful and beauty is sexy -- if it is visible.

Ms. Hesser cites a designer who says, ''Lighting is one of the most powerful tools that an architect has.'' I'm all in favor of giving power to architects if it doesn't take away power from diners. Those of us who patronize restaurants should not be denied the power to appreciate the beauty of our food, to read our menus, to see our companions and to enjoy the decor of our surroundings.
